bodies.name: Mercury
bodies.description: Mercury is the smallest planet in the Solar System. It’s classified as a terrestrial planet which means it’s primarily composed of silicate, rocks and metals. As a result of countless asteroids and other space rocks collisions, Mercury is heavily cratered. Mercury’s temperature can vary from -170°C to +420°C due to its long days that last approximately 88 Earth days.

bodies.name: Venus
bodies.description: Venus has the densest atmosphere out of all the terrestrial planets in the Solar System. Even though Venus is the second closest to the Sun, it’s by far the warmest planet at +464°C at the hottest. This is due to it being mostly composed of carbon dioxide which is a greenhouse gas. Venus has active volcanoes that release internal heat, resulting in resurfacing rather than plate tectonics which means that instead of the planet's surface being broken into shifting plates like on Earth, it undergoes periodic, large-scale volcanic resurfacing events.

bodies.name: Earth
bodies.description: Earth, also known as Terra, Tellus, Gaia, is the only planet known to currently harbor life and the planet you’re on right now! Earth’s ability to maintain environments hospitable to life is enabled by it being an ocean world and having an atmosphere and a magnetic field protecting it from solar winds and keeping it warm. Its crust is approximately 70% water while the remaining 30% is composed of continental landmasses with a variety of different environments.

bodies.name: Mars
bodies.description: Mars is the second smallest planet in the Solar System. Its orange-red color manifests because it’s covered in iron oxide dust. Mars has two natural satellites, Phobos and Deimos. While the northern parts of Mars are relatively flat, the southern parts have cratered highlands. There are notable temperature swings within a year that vary from -78°C to +5.7°C which are similar to Earth’s seasons, as they both have significant axial tilts.

bodies.name: Jupiter
bodies.description: Jupiter is the largest planet in the Solar System with an equatorial diameter of nearly 143 kilometers. It’s the third brightest natural object in the Earth’s night sky only surpassed by the Moon and Venus. Jupiter was the first planet to form in the Solar System and its presence affected much of the formation history of the other planets. Hydrogen accounts for 90% of Jupiter’s volume, followed by helium. Because of its strong gravitational pull, Jupiter is surrounded by a faint system of planetary rings that extend outward from the planet, composed mainly of dust and small particles.

bodies.name: Saturn
bodies.description: Saturn is the second largest planet in the Solar System and is most commonly recognized for its complex and highly visible ring system. These rings are composed mainly of water ice particles, with smaller amounts of rock and dust. Saturn is a gas giant, primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, much like Jupiter. Despite its size, Saturn has a relatively low density. Saturn is also known for its numerous moons among which Titan stands out as the largest, with a thick atmosphere and surface lakes of methane and ethane.

bodies.name: Uranus
bodies.description: Uranus, widely known for its hilarious name, is an ice giant, largely composed of oxygen, carbon and sulfur. It’s unique among planets because it orbits the Sun on its side, with an axial tilt of over 90 degrees. This unusual tilt causes extreme seasonal variations, with each pole experiencing 42 years of continuous sunlight followed by 42 years of darkness. Its bluish color comes from the methane in its atmosphere, which absorbs red light and reflects blue. Uranus has a faint ring system and is surrounded by 28 moons, with Miranda, Ariel, Umbriel, Titania, and Oberon, being the most notable.

bodies.name: Neptune
bodies.description: Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun and the coldest in the Solar System, with temperatures going as low as -200°C. It’s classified as an ice giant, like Uranus and is mostly composed of heavier elements and ices, such as water, ammonia, and methane. Neptune’s deep blue color is due to the presence of methane in its atmosphere. Despite its distance from the Sun, Neptune has the strongest winds in the Solar System, with speeds reaching up to 2,100 kilometers per hour. Neptune has a faint ring system and 16 moons, with Triton being the largest.
